perturbation.original_text: Amounts which remain unpaid for 30 days are subject to a finance charge of 1.5% per month on any outstanding balance, or the maximum permitted by law, whichever is lower, plus all expenses of collection and may result in immediate termination of Service.
perturbation.changed_text: Amounts which remain unpaid for 60 days are subject to a finance charge of 1.5% per month on any outstanding balance, or the maximum permitted by law, whichever is lower, plus all expenses of collection and may result in immediate termination of Service.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction. Initially, late fees and potential service termination apply after 30 days of non-payment. This change modifies the period to 60 days, which now creates confusion about when late fees are applied or services terminated. Does it happen after 30 days or 60?

perturbation.original_text: Subject to earlier termination as provided below, this Service Agreement is for the total duration of the Company's Offering (the "Initial Term") unless either party requests termination at least 30 days prior to the end of the then-current term.
perturbation.changed_text: Subject to earlier termination as provided below, this Service Agreement is for the total duration of the Company's Offering (the "Initial Term") unless either party requests termination at least 60 days prior to the end of the then-current term.
perturbation.explanation: This change creates an in-text contradiction regarding the termination notice period. Originally, a 30-day notice was required before the end of the term. This has been changed to 60 days, making it unclear which notice period applies and creating uncertainty in contract enforcement. This could lead to disputes if one party attempts to terminate with 30 days' notice, while the other party insists on 60.

perturbation.original_text: Additionally, either party may terminate this Service Agreement in the event: i) The other party's material breach that remains not cured and continues for a period of (A) in the case of a failure involving the payment of any undisputed amount due hereunder, 15 days and (B) in the case of any other failure, 30 days after the non performing party receives notice from the terminating party specifying such failure;
perturbation.changed_text: Additionally, either party may terminate this Service Agreement in the event: i) The other party's material breach that remains not cured and continues for a period of (A) in the case of a failure involving the payment of any undisputed amount due hereunder, 30 days and (B) in the case of any other failure, 30 days after the non performing party receives notice from the terminating party specifying such failure;
perturbation.explanation: This change alters the cure period for payment failure. Originally, a 15-day cure period was allowed for payment failures. It's now changed to 30 days. This directly conflicts with the original shorter timeframe, generating uncertainty about the grace period for payment defaults and the consequent ability to terminate for that reason.
